message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: "impels" vs "moves" in footnote 3">
**Quick question on footnote [^3] — "impels" vs "moves"**

Phenomenology flagged that footnote [^3] still has "impels" while the body text was changed to "moves me to want to."

But the two Chinese originals are different:
- **Body text** (line 24): 使得我**想要**去如何如何地对待他人 — "makes me **want to** treat the other..." → softer, hence "moves me to want to"
- **Footnote [^3]** (line 136): 这个感受使得（**推动**）我去做一些行为 — "this feeling makes (**pushes/impels**) me to do certain things" → stronger, 推动 = push/drive

Should "impels" stay in footnote [^3] since the original Chinese is actually stronger there (推动 vs 想要)? Or should we harmonize to "moves" for consistency?

Reply to team-lead: **KEEP "impels"** or **CHANGE to "moves"**, with brief reasoning.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**KEEP "impels."**

I was wrong to flag it. The Chinese is genuinely different: 推动 (push/drive) in the footnote is stronger than 想要 (want to) in the body. The translator correctly matched register to source — "impels" for 推动, "moves me to want to" for 使得我想要. Harmonizing would erase a real distinction in the original.

Good catch on the different source texts.
input.summary: KEEP "impels" — different Chinese source, my flag was wrong

routing.summary: KEEP "impels" — different Chinese source, my flag was wrong

Good catch on the different source texts.

content.text: **KEEP "impels"** in footnote [^3]. My original flag was wrong — the Chinese source texts are genuinely different. The body uses 想要 (want to), warranting the softer "moves me to want to." The footnote uses 推动 (push/drive), warranting the stronger "impels." The translator correctly matched English register to Chinese source in both cases. Harmonizing would erase a real distinction in the original.
